choices.D: It renders the data for easy use by the remaining parts of the design.
choices.B: It keeps views and controllers updated during the execution.
choices.C: It defines main application behavior and contains functions to run.

questions.question_text: What is impacted by the network bandwidth on an application?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Time taken for a data packet to travel between two endpoints (latency) depends on factors like distance, routing, and propagation delay. It is not directly tied to bandwidth.

so many mistakes in their answers. 
it is D

questions.question_text: A developer is trying to retrieve data over a REST API. The API server responds with an HTTP client error response code. After investigating the response, the developer realizes the response has a Retry-After header. What is the root cause of this error?

choices.D: An appliance limited the rate of requests to the application layer.
choices.A: An appliance limited the rate of requests to the transport layer.
choices.B: The REST service is unreachable at the time of the REST request.
choices.C: Too many requests were sent to the REST service in a given amount of time.

discussion.content:
C is the answer because the API Server is the one complaining about the rate.
The question states that the API Server itself is responding, and all other options would not be applicable to that case.

Selected Answer: C
The Retry-After response HTTP header indicates how long the user agent should wait before making a follow-up request. There are three main cases this header is used:

When sent with a 503 (Service Unavailable) response, this indicates how long the service is expected to be unavailable.
When sent with a 429 (Too Many Requests) response, this indicates how long to wait before making a new request.
When sent with a redirect response, such as 301 (Moved Permanently), this indicates the minimum time that the user agent is asked to wait before issuing the redirected request.
C is correct answer. Response code 429 is too many requests

HTTP headers are used to pass additional information with HTTP request or response. HTTP Retry-After header is an HTTP response header which indicates how long to wait before making another request. Depending on different status codes, there are different use cases of the Retry-After response header.

 - Status code 503: 503 is used to indicate service unavailable. Retry-After is used with 503 which tells the user how long the service is expected to be unavailable. It is used to deal with scheduled downtime.
 - Status code 301: 301 is used to indicate that resource is moved permanently. Retry-After is used with 301 which tells the user about the minimum for which user should wait before issuing the redirect request.
 - Status code 429: 429 id is used to indicate too many request. Retry-After is used with 429 to tells the user how long to wait before making another request.

The question says: "The API server responds with an HTTP client error response code." If the response is from the server then the code is 503, and then it is because of unavailability of the service. So, option B is the correct.

comments.content: Forget it, it's a client error response code, it's 429 then. It's C the correct one. Sorry.

discussion.content:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Retry-After

Its C.
If it's A,B or D. The connection will timeout. Depending on how it is timeout you can have a 504 or not answer at all. Either way, you will not have this message. 

The only way you have a "retry-after" is because you got a 503 and that happens only when a server is busy. A server is busy when they can not handle more request (even if the requests are really low number as 0). So either way, are "too many requests"

When sent with a 503 (Service Unavailable) response, this indicates how long the service is expected to be unavailable.

questions.question_text: Which network device plane is responsible for handling QoS?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
it should be Control plane . Correct Answer : D

B. Data plane
The data plane is responsible for forwarding traffic based on the rules set by the control plane. It handles QoS (Quality of Service) by enforcing policies for traffic prioritization, shaping, and scheduling.

It is B : The data plane (also known as the forwarding plane) is primarily responsible for handling Quality of Service (QoS) in network devices. The data plane manages the actual forwarding of packets through the router or switch, and it includes features like QoS and access control lists (ACLs) to ensure efficient and prioritized packet handling

Selected Answer: D
The control plane performs forwarding decisions and other functions, like quality of service (QoS). In contrast, the data plane is the network that switches or forwards devices handling the data packets and taking inputs from the control plane.
